Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Engineering Education Research: Understanding and Improving Student Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site is providing engineering undergraduate students the opportunity to engage in research in engineering education. Olin College is committed to understanding and improving undergraduate engineering education, and many of the faculty have active research programs in this area. Ten undergraduate students and two high school teachers each summer are working closely with Olin faculty on a wide range of research projects. For example, some teams are researching how engineering content is taught in colleges and universities, which is resulting in new educational materials and practices. Others are focusing on how to better develop professional and interpersonal skills, such as communication and teamwork, that complement technical engineering training. Still others are examining how being in an engineering program affects students' self-confidence, identity, and interest in engineering careers. The outcomes of the research are improving the recruitment, retention, and preparation of engineering students. The REU students are learning about educational research through their participation, which is also increasing their likelihood of continuing in engineering. All program participants, including teachers and professors, are reflecting on their own experiences in engineering and are becoming stronger advocates for improving engineering education at their institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of three summers, from 2013 to 2015, the Olin Summer Experiences in Education Research program engaged a total of thirty-four undergraduate students and six middle- and high-school teachers in research and curricular development in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM). The students came from all over the country and a wide range of institutions of higher education, and most of them were enrolled in undergraduate engineering programs. The teachers were all based at schools in the vicinity of Olin College. The students engaged in research designed to understand and support different aspects of the STEM student experience, while the teachers designed curricular units focused on their specific school populations, together with research tools to evaluate their effectiveness. All participants were mentored by Olin College researchers. Over the course of each summer, a tightly-knit community formed, which allowed for the sharing of research practices and findings, fostered supportive critique, and built a community of practice amongst the undergraduate researchers, local teachers, and Olin College mentors. After engaging deeply with the student experience through a summer of research in education, students returned to their home institutions with a new perspective on their own education; similarly, teachers returned to their schools newly empowered to create and evaluate STEM-based experiences for their students, and to share what they learned with their colleagues. Many of the summer research projects were presented at major national and international education conferences, and a number of the students have gone on to graduate programs in engineering education research.

Some examples of many projects undertaken by summer research students include:

An analysis of why female African-American engineering graduates remain in the field or choose to leave;

How students express dissatisfaction with their peers in team projects, and what that can teach us about how to design better teaming experiences for undergraduate engineering students;

Using Rube Goldberg machines as an entry point to learning engineering for students in diverse, urban high schools, thereby increasing access to the field;

Understanding how student beliefs about faculty care and gender affects their motivation in introductory chemistry courses.

More information about the program can be found at: http://www.olin.edu/collaborate/collaboratory/attend/seer/
